articles.title: Physicists are uncovering when nature’s strongest force falters
articles.summary: The strong nuclear force may abruptly loosen its grip on the fundamental particles that make up matter at a special “critical point” – researchers are now getting a clearer picture of when that point is reached
articles.content:
The strong nuclear force may abruptly loosen its grip on the fundamental particles that make up matter at a special “critical point” – researchers are now getting a clearer picture of when that point is reached

The STAR detector at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider BROOKHAVEN NATIONAL LABORATORY

We are getting closer to understanding when the strong nuclear force loosens its grip on the most basic constituents of matter, letting quarks and gluons inside particles abruptly turn into a hot particle soup.

There is a special combination of temperature and pressure at which all three phases of water – liquid, ice and vapour – exist simultaneously. For decades, researchers have been looking for a similar “critical point” for matter governed by the strong nuclear force, which binds quarks and gluons into protons and neutrons.

Smashing ions in particle colliders can create a state where the strong force breaks down and allows quarks and gluons to form a soupy “quark-gluon plasma”. But it remains murky whether this transition is preceded by a critical point. Xin Dong at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in California and his colleagues have now gotten closer to clearing it up.

They analysed the number and distribution of particles created in the aftermath of a smash-up of two very energetic gold ions at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider at Brookhaven National Laboratory in New York state. Dong says they were effectively trying to create a phase diagram for quarks and gluons – a map showing what types of matter the strong force allows to form under different circumstances. The new experiment didn’t pin down the critical point on this map with great certainty, but it significantly narrowed the region where it could be.

There is a part of the phase diagram where matter “melts” into plasma gradually, like butter softening on the counter, but the critical point would align with a more abrupt transition, like chunks of ice suddenly appearing in liquid water, says Agnieszka Sorensen at the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams in Michigan, who wasn’t involved in the work. The new experiment will serve not only as a guide for where to look for this point, but it has also revealed which particle properties may offer the best clues that it exists, she says.

Claudia Ratti at the University of Houston in Texas says that many researchers have been excitedly anticipating this new analysis because it yielded a precision that previous measurements couldn’t achieve, and did so for a part of the phase diagram where theoretical calculations are notoriously difficult. Recently, several predictions for the critical point location have converged, and the challenge for experimentalists will be to analyse the data for the even lower collision energies corresponding to these predictions, she says.

An unambiguous detection of the critical point would be a generational breakthrough, says Dong. This is in part because the strong force is the only fundamental force that physicists suspect has a critical point. Additionally, this force has played a significant role in shaping our universe: it governed the properties of hot and dense matter created right after the big bang, and it is still dictating the structure of neutron stars. Dong says collider experiments like the new one could help us understand what goes on inside of these exotic cosmic objects once we complete the strong force phase diagram.

articles.personality_title: Scientists narrow down when nature’s strongest force changes state
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The strong nuclear force is what holds together the tiny particles inside atoms, like quarks and gluons. Scientists have long wondered if this force suddenly changes how it works at a special set of conditions, called a “critical point,” similar to how water can be ice, liquid, or steam depending on temperature and pressure.

**What happened** – Researchers at Brookhaven National Laboratory used a machine called the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider to smash gold ions together at very high energy. By studying the particles created in these collisions, they mapped out where the strong force might change suddenly. Their new data did not find the exact critical point but greatly narrowed down where it could be.

**Impact** – This work helps scientists better understand the strong nuclear force, which is unique because it might have this special critical point. Knowing where it happens could explain how matter behaved just after the Big Bang and what happens inside neutron stars, some of the densest objects in space.

**What's next step** – Researchers will now look at collisions with even lower energies to try to pinpoint the critical point more exactly. This will help complete the map of how the strong force works under different conditions.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New experiments have brought scientists closer to discovering the exact conditions where the strong nuclear force shifts, revealing more about the universe’s most fundamental matter.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques précisent le moment où la force la plus forte de la nature change d’état
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La force nucléaire forte maintient ensemble les toutes petites particules à l’intérieur des atomes, comme les quarks et les gluons. Les scientifiques se demandent depuis longtemps si cette force change soudainement de comportement à un point spécial appelé « point critique », un peu comme l’eau qui peut être glace, liquide ou vapeur selon la température et la pression.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs du laboratoire national de Brookhaven ont utilisé un appareil appelé le collisionneur d’ions lourds relativistes pour écraser des ions d’or à très haute énergie. En étudiant les particules créées lors de ces collisions, ils ont tracé une carte des endroits où la force forte pourrait changer brusquement. Leur nouvelle analyse n’a pas trouvé le point critique exact, mais a fortement réduit la zone où il pourrait se trouver.

**Impact** – Ce travail aide les scientifiques à mieux comprendre la force nucléaire forte, unique car elle pourrait avoir ce point critique spécial. Savoir où il se situe pourrait expliquer comment la matière se comportait juste après le Big Bang et ce qui se passe à l’intérieur des étoiles à neutrons, parmi les objets les plus denses de l’espace.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs vont maintenant étudier des collisions à énergies encore plus basses pour essayer de localiser plus précisément le point critique. Cela aidera à compléter la carte du fonctionnement de la force forte dans différentes conditions.

**Résumé en une phrase** – De nouvelles expériences rapprochent les scientifiques de la découverte des conditions exactes où la force nucléaire forte change, révélant davantage sur la matière la plus fondamentale de l’univers.
articles.personality_title_es: Los científicos acotan cuándo la fuerza más fuerte de la naturaleza cambia de estado
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La fuerza nuclear fuerte es la que mantiene unidas las partículas muy pequeñas dentro de los átomos, como los quarks y gluones. Durante mucho tiempo, los científicos se han preguntado si esta fuerza cambia repentinamente su forma de actuar en un punto especial llamado “punto crítico”, similar a cómo el agua puede ser hielo, líquido o vapor según la temperatura y la presión.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores del Laboratorio Nacional Brookhaven usaron un aparato llamado Colisionador Relativista de Iones Pesados para chocar iones de oro a muy alta energía. Al estudiar las partículas creadas en estas colisiones, trazaron un mapa de dónde podría cambiar de forma brusca la fuerza fuerte. Su nuevo análisis no encontró el punto crítico exacto, pero redujo mucho la región donde podría estar.

**Impacto** – Este trabajo ayuda a los científicos a entender mejor la fuerza nuclear fuerte, que es especial porque podría tener este punto crítico único. Saber dónde está podría explicar cómo se comportaba la materia justo después del Big Bang y qué ocurre dentro de las estrellas de neutrones, algunos de los objetos más densos del espacio.

**Próximo paso** – Ahora los investigadores estudiarán colisiones con energías aún más bajas para intentar localizar con más precisión el punto crítico. Esto ayudará a completar el mapa de cómo funciona la fuerza fuerte en diferentes condiciones.

**Resumen en una frase** – Nuevos experimentos acercan a los científicos a descubrir las condiciones exactas donde la fuerza nuclear fuerte cambia, revelando más sobre la materia más fundamental del universo.
